title: At close of business on 31 December 2021, will Apple be the most valuable publicly traded company in the world?
possible_answers: Yes, the most valuable in the world
No, but the most valuable in the United States
correct_answer: Yes, the most valuable in the world
preds: Virtually certain that it is Apple...

I'm moving closer to even chances between MSFT and AAPL, but with a 1% chance ( 0.635% as per the simulation)  of ARAMCO being the largest. The reason ARAMCO still has such a high chance is because AAPL and MSFT are highly correlated whereas ARAMCO is much more independent.

Apple's new M1 silicon for laptop computers is being recognized as a true breakthrough in performance.  See https://www.nytimes.com/2021/11/10/opinion/apple-microprocessor.html.  Checking availability at apple.com, I found that if I were to order one today it would arrive early December. Apple has a pretty good history of anticipating demand, so I suspect they have a lot of product in the pipeline.  Barring production hiccups or shipping problems the new computers could add to AAPL's FY22 profitability.  True, there isn't enough time to affect this quarter's numbers.  But the stock market is anticipatory; it doesn't wait for earnings reports to move the stock price.  Also, in the short term AAPL's price is all about iPhone sales numbers. Shortly after Facebook's name change to Meta, Microsoft announced it's plans for the meta verse.  See https://www.investopedia.com/microsoft-msft-integrates-metaverse-into-its-software-5208328.  At this point it seems more like a PR move than a significant announcement, but admittedly I'm not a software expert.  Most new technologies go through a hype phase (more like overhype) before they become truly useful.  But such announcements can boost a company's stock price. So it's very unclear which company will have the highest market value in only 7 1/2 weeks.  I'll give AAPL the edge, but less so than the crowd.  To me it's a toss up, but I won't go that much against the crowd.

I put together a quick version of a Monte Carlo simulation that forces AAPL, MSFT, and ARAMCO to move according to how they are directionally correlated with respect to AAPL (e.g. in the real world, MSFT moves the same direction as AAPL about 77% of the time, so they must also share the same directionality 77% of the time in the simulation).  I'm also using the same technique here: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1349335 h/t @elifland for being spot on. I'm moving even closer to your most recent forecast. SIMULATION RESULTS: { "AAPL": 45.5%, "MSFT": 53.75%, "ARAMCO": 0.75%}
CODE: https://github.com/jonathanmann/gjopen/blob/master/apple_most_valuable/apple_relative.py

Considering the above 2 points, I am estimating a base rate of about 60-70% of Apple being the most valuable company  [1] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_public_corporations_by_market_capitalization

In my head, I have to re-phrase this question. Considering Apple has been the most valuable company for the past 3 years, what would it take to change that? Either Apple's market value shrinks or another company flies past. Apple's market value has grown quarter on quarter consistently over the past 3 years except for Q1 of 2021 and a sharp fall on Q4 2018. However, those quarters were generally weaker for most listed companies (especially the latter) and may well not have to do anything with the companies' performance (sidenote: does market cap really have anything to do with performance anyway?). Average market cap growth % for apple has been 11% for a 3-year period and 16% for 2020. Amazon and Microsoft both get an average 9% rate for a 3-year period and Amazon has a 17% growth rate for 2020 when it picked up a lot of speed. Whereas I see that in the past Apple has been overtaken by Microsoft at some point, the gap between them is larger than it has been over the past 3 years. Based on that history, I'd say it's unlikely for Amazon, Microsoft or Alphabet to beat their own track record and overtake Apple. However, I'll say Amazon's performance merits closer follow-up going forward as the pandemic seems to have boosted its market cap. This leaves me to have a look at two other companies that have not been on this list over the past 3 years. One is Tesla and the other is SA (Saudi Aramco). Tesla has skyrocketed into the top 10 recently but it's hard to assess growth rate as it is a new contender. There's a lot of talk about it but I wonder, will it even pass the $1tn mark in 2021? To go from $806bn to $2tn+ just to contend with Apple would completely unprecedented and would defy any record-breaking growth rates noted above. It'd say it's very unlikely but it would also be wonderful to see. That leaves me with SA. Another tough pick because it doesn't have such a long history in the market. Market cap grew about 9% from 2019 to 2020. It's a bit of a wild car considering it's state-directed and the myriad ramifications of the oil industry. Even Biden's policies on environment and energy may have a knock-on effect on this market cap. At this point, I'll stick to the simple fact that it's growing 9% year-on-year (although that's not a strong reference point) and Apple is still beating that rate. I will keep a very close eye on the oil industry to revise my forecast. So, let's recap. Over the past 3 years, the same company has staid 3 out of 4 months as top-valued and twice has Apple closed as the most valuable. Apple has sat on number 1 for 7 quarters out of 12. So let's start with that. 58% chance Even as a starting point, it's good because the gap between Apple and the rest of American companies at this point is large so there's margin to increase that on the home front.  I'll say there is a 58% chance it's the most valuable in the world and 67% chance that at least remains so in the US (the extra points at home is for the fact that only 1 quarter out of 12 did Apple shrink and any of its competitors stayed stable or manage to perform better). I have to make this fit into the 100/3 format so I'm weighing these probabilities and come up with: 
58% for Apple because I reckon that number stills holds
Out of the remaining 42%
26% for remaining the most valuable US company
16% for no I'm sorry if this was too convoluted but I want to keep a record of my rationale. I'll update as my thinking may change.
Not sure which american company is betting on to overthrow Apple but I think people should start some arbitrage if they think Apple is so much likely to lose its throne

Conditions are too tight to be committed. It may happen during the year but as a close out value for 2021, there may be other parameters that may affect. inflation, forex, solar, energy, Microsoft, Aramco, and even Tesla.

The crowd has moved strongly towards "NO," which requires that one of the other tech companies passes AAPL.  The most likely are MSFT and AMZN, but they have to make up a pretty large gap of over 33%.  It has happened in the recent past, and could happen again.  But I don't see it as the most probable event.  A global economic recovery brought about by vaccines could make this a big year for energy.  So it seems more likely that ARAMCO wins over big tech, or that AAPL keeps the lead.

Apple is currently the largest, so this answer will resolve to yes unless something changes the status quo. Thinking about how this question might become a "no" the companies to watch are Saudi Aramco, Microsoft, Amazon, Google, Tesla, and Tencent. Apple loses the top spot if one or more of these companies grows faster than Apple, or if Apple loses more market capitalization than at least one of these companies.  I'd put a low probability that Tesla and/or Tencent can catch up by the end of 2021. Those companies are each about a third of Apple's current size. I'd also put a low probability of Microsoft of Google catching Apple this year, seeing as they are all in the same sector and not growing faster than Apple. I've placed 42% chance that SA comes out with the top spot, most likely due to a fall in US equities relative to oil. There's also a chance that SA sells more stock and increases its capitalization that way. Conversely, oil prices could rise rapidly and increase the share price of SA significantly (although a low probability event). I'm adding another 2% to the second option to account for the possibility of another foreign company (maybe Tencent or Alibaba) taking off and passing Apple.  If a foreign company isn't in the top spot, and Apple isn't the top US company, another US company must pass them. The most likely challenger is Amazon, with a current value 38% below Apple. Another possibility is Tesla seeing another tremendous year while Apple does not. Again, the difference in current market cap leads me to think those are not high probability events. I've assigned a combined probability of 7% that at least one of those things happen. If the gap shrinks, I'll adjust those odds higher.   Thinking through this question, it seems like the most sensitive uncertainties are oil prices and Amazon growth.

The question to me is not so much which company appreciates fastest in 2021, because I do not expect the extraordinary year 2020 for the stock market to repeat, but instead which company in a very difficult year ahead will have such a stable and profitable (with regards to margins) business model that it is going to lose least market cap. The stock market isn't going to get any better than that.
Apple has a good portfolio of software, hardware, services, even financial services, and is innovative enough to maybe become the first 3-trillion-USD company within five years. I don't think any competitor or contender in this question has an edge over Apple. A lot of impact on profitability (and thus market cap) will depend on tax regimes worldwide, and which of the (mostly) companies is best and most aggressive in negotiating the most ridiculously low tax rates in one of the many half-baked tax domiciles. Unless there is major consensus among G20 that tax fraud and evasion must end, and tax regimes finally change.
Potential upcoming tech regulation in the US, continued strength of Amazon with ongoing pandemic
See this being a big year for Microsoft.
Initial forecast -- with nearly one year to go anything can happen.  I'm less confident about AAPL being #1 than the crowd.
If there is a market drop, likely Saudi Aramco will drop similarly to Apple. So the biggest chance for "No" is some tech company exceeding Apple's market cap.
Premium revenues may be threatened by COVID recession. Privacy concerns will help. Chinese mega Corps could well overtake, esp with better market access

I think there is a reasonable chance that gridlock in Congress will harm the economy and cut into the iphone market in combination with anti-trust issues brought on by the Epic Games suit.  This coupled growth in China since they seem to be able to handle Covid.  Also EVs are booming so its also possible that Tesla could over take them in the US, but that is less likely. According to https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_public_corporations_by_market_capitalization#2020, absent large shifts in technology, the top three places in companies by market capitalization are largely stable and often occupied by the same group (past ten years - Apple, Amazon, Alphabet, Microsoft, BH, Exxon Mobil).  Since 2016 the top places have been dominated by A/A/A/M (the four 1T+ US companies) and there is no indication that this will change due to currently foreseeable economic conditions of 2021.  Apple currently has a sizeable lead of over 500bn over second place MSFT and the biggest non-pandemic drop it has seen in the last five years is ~14%. Over the past five years MSFT has grown at a CAGR of 33%, so even based only on historical trends it is very much possible for MSFT to overtake APPL, without even going into P/E ratios, overvaluation, possible effects of US stimulus, etc.  A quick search of large non-public entities reveals nothing in the $1T range, so outcome B is largely the same as P(SA becomes most valuable company & APPL maintains lead over A/A/M). Given historical growth rates of oil vs technology and the increasing separation this seems like an unlikely scenario.
It's more likely that Apple will be most valuable in the US, than in world. And the least probable that no change would occur.
It looks reasonable that with the recently launched subscription services it would keep growing.

First, we may be entering a tech bubble that could burst during the year.  Considering that Apple's competitors are also within this sector, a decline in their market cap would equate to the same for them.  In a post-COVID environment, the oil/energy sector should see a rise that could generate additional market cap for ARAMCO that could allow it to pass Apple.  Additionally, the Chinese economy and Alibaba (even with the investigation) could grow greater than any US competitor.

I looked at the daily year-on-year changes of the market cap of the big tech companies over the last 4 years and worked out how often, if extrapolated into the future, they would beat Apple's predicted (by the same method) minimum, lower/upper quartiles, and mean (I ignored the max in order to be a bit conservative). Weighting each equally, in 34% of cases one or both of Microsoft or Amazon had a higher predicted market cap. However, this assumed Aramco stays stable (as it roughly has since it floated). I don't know very much about Aramco, although I think it more likely than not that tech will grow faster than oil next year. I massaged the numbers a bit to reflect this uncertainty. As a sanity check I was pleased to see my somewhat idiosyncratic methodology produced a similar result to the current crowd forecast.
Microsoft and Amazon more likely given continued rise of cloud tech & enterprise comms during 2021

A year is a logn shot, but that's what makes it interesting. Going down into sub-questions, we can say:
The Tech bubble. Just comparing current prices to Feb ones, there was a significant increase probably not justified by creation of value. My guess is there is a bubble that will burst with household savings being spent.
Also, it seems that the winners from the pandemic are Apple and Amazon, for individual, stay-at-home reasons. Microsoft and Google also performed well, but not as well.
The oil vs other cleaner energy. During this time, Aramco was relatively stable, about +10% variance to pre-COVID. Not that it makes a lot of sense with current oil prices compared to Feb. (just to compare, S&P 500 increased by 20% and DJIA by 18%). It doesn't seem reasonable that other options are considered in this situation and short period, and the barrel price could likely increase with activity.
So, "all" is needed is Apple to drop about 16% to be below Market Cap of pre-COVID Aramco. At this point, it is more likely to happen than not.
The other question would be In terms of the US companies and the competition between consumers and businesses. This is hard to say. The difference between Apple and Microsoft is huge, but the market correction, if there is any, would be too. Pre-COVID, both companies were aligned in Market Cap.
My guess is that it will be slightly better for Microsoft or Amazon than for Apple, as business will still need their services, while fewer business will be open, but surely consumers will not need the latest iPhone or iPad.
Sources: https://finance.yahoo.com

That is primarily why it didnt get listed on an international stock exchange(Very few takers for a $2tn valuation). The only scenario where prospects for Aramco can turn for the better is one where oil prices strengthen(With UAE a traditional ally now eyeing a stronger presence in OPEC) this possibility seems remote. Barred any major frictions in global supply chains or smashes to US, China or global purchase power and demand for CE, Apple R&D will likely be more productive economically than low tech pumping of crude oil. As KSA has one of the lowest production costs (likely still between 15 to 20USD/bbl)  AND the one of the highest inventory of confirmed reserves worldwide Saudi Aramco's enterprise value will largely depend on the global average crude oil price level: if prices for SA grades rise to 50USD/bbl, then Saudi Aramco's earnings in the worst case will be 60cents on the dollat of sales, if prices climb to as much as 70USD/bbl, a level previously seen in the wake of the Sept 2019 Abqaiq–Khurais attack, its earnings are scaled up to 71cents on the dollar of sales.
At a revenue of 329.8bn USD (FY 2019), Saudi had an operating income of 177,8bn USD (53.9%, FY2019) and a net income of 88.2bn USD (26.7% of revenue, FY 2019).
Most of net income will be distributed as dividend in 2020 again, where both AAPL and Saudi Aramco have a similar peculiarity in their financial position and their financing structure, in that they use debt funding for dividend payments to lower costs of funding.
"Aramco said it would distribute a dividend of $18.75 billion for the quarter, in line with its plan to pay a base dividend of $75 billion for 2020.
But equity analyst Yousef Husseini at investment bank EFG-Hermes said Aramco would likely have to increase its debt financing in the short- to medium-term, or further cut capital expenditure, in order to be able to maintain the dividend unless oil prices recovered to at least $55 a barrel."
https://uk.reuters.com/article/us-saudi-aramco-results-idUKKBN27J0K3 In a simplified model of Saudi Aramco's business, their need for a swift and sustainable recovery of the global oil market in order to turn into the global wealth-generating machine #1 and a cash/dividend transforming laundromat slot-machine (your net notional paid for the stock of today will predictably be reimbursed completely by distributed net income/dividends within the next 15 years) again that the KSA needs becomes obvious:
/ at an annual production of 600mn bbl of crude and 20USD/bbl constant cost for production (assumed total production would be exported as crude), total cost for production are fixed at 12bn USD annually.
/ at an annual average crude price (FY2021) of 50USD/bbl, the total production would be valued at a gross value of 30bn USD and a net value of 18bn USD
/at an annual average crude price (FY2021) of 70USD/bbl, the total production would be valued at a gross value of 42bn USD and a net value of 30bn USD
Thus, a price increase of 40% would cause an increase in value added of roughly 66.7% which means a leverage of more than 1.5.  In reality the majority of profits will be generated in the refinery business, in storing and logistics, and not least Saudi Aramco is a financial superpower that has direct and financial investments likely on all continents; however, the lever Saudi Aramco has in their business is unique and will fully come into play when oil prices surpass 65USD on average (Saudi would then likely surpass Apple's target operating margin of 30% of revenue). It is, however, questionable whether or not 15 years from now (year 2035) the business model of Saudi Aramco will still exist. Further stringent climate action politics in 2021 may lower Saudi Aramco's market cap by a discount of 3-6%, which could in the end be the crucial margin.

Apples increase in value in 2020 was largely due to the overall boom in the US stock market which was fueled by the easy money created by the federal reserve. This easy money tended to benefit certain places, such as high profile stocks such as FANG stocks. Therefore, any major stock market crash will likely see the opposite effect with a larger amount of value coming out of these overpriced stocks that have benefited the most from this bubble.  I expect both a major stock market correction and a weakening of the dollar, perhaps a collapse of the dollar, in 2021. I expect Apple to still remain the largest us-based company, but I think the crash of the dollar will see apple lose ground against other international companies.  This is difficult to forecast because nothing like this has ever happened before. We have not had a world reserve currency crash in about 70 years, and this time it will be much different than last time. This ship is so massive that it has a lot of momentum and it is hard to know when it will finally sink. I think the deciding blow for the United States system will be rising inflation, and I think it is likely that will really pick up this year. I expect massive bailout packages this year for States, for everyone. Money printing on a scale much more massive than even 2020.

With the high value of tech stocks and the long timeframe on the question I feel more confident that a correction will happen at some point next year. But these things are hard to predict and a correction might not mean a big drop, it could mean slower gains as other companies catch up. Or I could be totally wrong and a correction won't even happen. I think there's a very good chance Apple stays as the most valuable company in the US since I think most other valuable tech stocks will continue to follow a similar trend as Apple does.
